Comment:
Welcome to a short but explosive annotation, a game which from quiet beginnings erupts into a devastating double sac attack leading to a resounding win for black in less than 20 moves.

Queens pawn opening, not one I play, but I come across it often now and am fairly comfortable playing against.
My usual response....
Immediately striving to dominate the center of the board, as black I don't think it's best to break the strain at the first time of asking...
So I lend support and open up space for my K's bishop to enter the game...
The pawn still isn't worth giving up the center for in my opinion, so...
Forming a solid pawn structure at the expense of impeding my Knights natural spot of c6...
Shutting the door on c4 for free.
More development....
Almost mirroring each others movements, nothing seems out of place.....
Almost mirroring each others movements, nothing seems out of place.....
Almost mirroring each others movements, nothing seems out of place.....
Almost mirroring each others movements, nothing seems out of place.....
Almost mirroring each others movements, nothing seems out of place.....
Almost mirroring each others movements, nothing seems out of place.....
I don't see how this move was more important than to play 0-0 here, and seems a waste to me.....
I try and complete my development and feel as if I have gained a tempo in the process..
This rook slide proves a very important move, without it my plan comes to nothing....
This rook slide proves a very important move, without it my plan comes to nothing....
Opening up space for some kind of attack coming from the queenside?
This  was risky but I really liked this move, as, unless he wants to trade the bishop it's fairly safe and I wanted it to stay there for as long as poss...
Now my Q's Bishop is free to enter the fight and I dominate much of the board...
Now my Q's Bishop is free to enter the fight and I dominate much of the board...
This is a little annoying, but there's no way I'm gonna take it....
Now this is where I started to think about a sac, not realising just quite how well it would turn out...
